Section 4(b) of Public Law 94-241 is amended to limit payments to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands to amounts set forth in a multi-year funding agreement. Additional amounts can be made available to the Secretary for obligation as specified. For fiscal year 1996, all amounts are provided for capital infrastructure projects in American Samoa. For fiscal years 1997 and beyond, the funds are available solely for capital infrastructure projects in Guam, the Virgin Islands, American Samoa, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, the Republic of Palau, the Federated States of Micronesia, and the Republic of the Marshall Islands. In fiscal year 1997, $3 million is allocated to the College of the Northern Marianas, and up to $3 million annually may be used for immigration, labor, and law enforcement issues in the Northern Mariana Islands. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with island governments, will develop a five-year plan for infrastructure assistance, with priority projects identified. Considerations include master plans, Corps of Engineers' reviews, maintenance needs, local cost-share requirements, and a possible $2 million annual set-aside. The bill includes a provision for a $2 million annual emergency fund for natural disasters and infrastructure repair, with a cap of $10 million. Additional contributions may be made for the resettlement of Rongelap Atoll, not exceeding $32 million, subject to specific conditions. Each Federal agency providing assistance in the Republic of the Marshall Islands can make funds available for the resettlement of Rongelap through the Secretary of the Interior. Ex gratia assistance can also be provided under certain conditions, with the requirement that all funds necessary for resettlement at Rongelap must be provided before assistance for individuals not choosing to resettle can be given. SEC. 2. FEDERAL MINIMUM WAGE. Effective thirty days after enactment, the minimum wage provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act apply to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. The minimum wage rates will start at $2.75 per hour, increasing to $3.05 per hour in 1996, and then raised annually by thirty cents or to match the federal minimum wage rate. The minimum wage rate in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands will be set according to the Fair Labor Standards Act. The minimum wage rate in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands will be set according to the Fair Labor Standards Act. SEC. 3. REPORT. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with other government officials, must report to Congress by March 15 each year on funds allocated for immigration, labor, and law enforcement activities. The report includes immigration data, treatment of non-US citizen workers, and the impact of CNMI laws on Federal interests. The Secretary of the Interior must report to Congress annually on funds allocated for immigration, labor, and law enforcement activities in the Northern Mariana Islands. The report covers immigration data, treatment of non-US citizen workers, adequacy of detention facilities, accuracy of alien identification system, and reasons for federal agencies' enforcement challenges. SEC. 4. IMMIGRATION COOPERATION. The Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands and the Immigration and Naturalization Service will work together to identify and, if necessary, exclude or deport individuals posing security or law enforcement risks to the Commonwealth or the United States. SEC. 5. CLARIFICATION OF LOCAL EMPLOYMENT IN THE MARIANAS. Section 8103(i) of title 46 of the United States Code is amended to allow aliens in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands to work as unlicensed seamen on certain vessels within US waters. This amendment excludes them from certain employment restrictions. SEC. 6 amends Public Law 93-435 to clarify ownership of submerged lands in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. It includes changes to references in sections 1 and 2 regarding Guam, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, and the Virgin Islands. References to enactment dates in the law now refer to the date of enactment of this section. SEC. 7 requires an annual State of the Islands report. SEC. 7 mandates an annual "State of the Islands" report to Congress on various territories, including economic data, federal assistance, infrastructure, financial management, and federal efforts to improve capabilities. SEC. 8 makes a technical correction to Public Law 95-134 by updating references to Pacific Island territories. The Secretary, Kelly D. Johnston, attests to the document.
